# 300 win club

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![A black-and-white photograph of a man from the chest up looking to his
right, wearing a baseball uniform with the letters "B" and
"A".](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Cy_Young.jpg/200px-
Cy_Young.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cy_Young.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cy_Young.jpg "Enlarge")

[Cy Young](/wiki/Cy_Young "Cy Young") is the all-time leader in wins.

In [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball"), the **300 win club** is the group of [pitchers](/wiki/Pitcher
"Pitcher") who have [won](/wiki/Win_\(baseball\) "Win \(baseball\)") 300 or
more games. Twenty-four pitchers have reached this milestone. The New York
Gothams/Giants/San Francisco Giants are the only franchise to see three
players reach the milestone while on their roster: those players are [Mickey
Welch](/wiki/Mickey_Welch "Mickey Welch"), [Christy
Mathewson](/wiki/Christy_Mathewson "Christy Mathewson"), and [Randy
Johnson](/wiki/Randy_Johnson "Randy Johnson"). Early in the history of
professional baseball, many of the rules favored the pitcher over the batter;
the distance pitchers threw to home plate was shorter than today, and pitchers
were able to use foreign substances to alter the direction of the ball.[1] The
first player to win 300 games was [Pud Galvin](/wiki/Pud_Galvin "Pud Galvin")
in 1888. Seven pitchers recorded all or the majority of their career wins in
the 19th century: Galvin, [Cy Young](/wiki/Cy_Young "Cy Young"), [Kid
Nichols](/wiki/Kid_Nichols "Kid Nichols"), [Tim Keefe](/wiki/Tim_Keefe "Tim
Keefe"), [John Clarkson](/wiki/John_Clarkson "John Clarkson"), [Charley
Radbourn](/wiki/Charley_Radbourn "Charley Radbourn"), and [Mickey
Welch](/wiki/Mickey_Welch "Mickey Welch").[2] Four more pitchers joined the
club in the first quarter of the 20th century: [Christy
Mathewson](/wiki/Christy_Mathewson "Christy Mathewson"), [Walter
Johnson](/wiki/Walter_Johnson "Walter Johnson"), [Eddie
Plank](/wiki/Eddie_Plank "Eddie Plank"), and [Grover Cleveland
Alexander](/wiki/Grover_Cleveland_Alexander "Grover Cleveland Alexander").[1]
Young is the all-time leader in wins with 511, a mark that is considered
[unbreakable](/wiki/List_of_Major_League_Baseball_records_considered_unbreakable
"List of Major League Baseball records considered unbreakable").[3] If a
modern-day pitcher won 20 games per season for 25 seasons, he would still be
11 games short of Young's mark.

Only three pitchers, [Lefty Grove](/wiki/Lefty_Grove "Lefty Grove"), [Warren
Spahn](/wiki/Warren_Spahn "Warren Spahn"), and [Early Wynn](/wiki/Early_Wynn
"Early Wynn"), joined the 300 win club between 1924 and 1982, which may be
explained by a number of factors: the abolition of the
[spitball](/wiki/Spitball "Spitball"),[1][a] [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II") military service, such as [Bob Feller](/wiki/Bob_Feller "Bob
Feller")'s,[5] and the growing importance of the [home run](/wiki/Home_run
"Home run") in the game.[1] As the home run became commonplace, the physical
and mental demands on pitchers dramatically increased, which led to the use of
a four-man starting rotation.[1][2] Between 1982 and 1990, the 300 win club
gained six members: [Gaylord Perry](/wiki/Gaylord_Perry "Gaylord Perry"),
[Phil Niekro](/wiki/Phil_Niekro "Phil Niekro"), [Steve
Carlton](/wiki/Steve_Carlton "Steve Carlton"), [Nolan Ryan](/wiki/Nolan_Ryan
"Nolan Ryan"), [Don Sutton](/wiki/Don_Sutton "Don Sutton") and [Tom
Seaver](/wiki/Tom_Seaver "Tom Seaver").[2] These pitchers benefited from the
increased use of specialized [relief pitchers](/wiki/Relief_pitchers "Relief
pitchers"), an expanded [strike zone](/wiki/Strike_zone "Strike zone"), and
new stadiums, including [Shea Stadium](/wiki/Shea_Stadium "Shea Stadium"),
[Dodger Stadium](/wiki/Dodger_Stadium "Dodger Stadium") and the
[Astrodome](/wiki/Astrodome "Astrodome"), that were [pitcher's
parks](/wiki/Pitcher%27s_park "Pitcher's park"), which suppressed offensive
production.[2] Also, the increasing sophistication of training methods and
sports medicine, such as [Tommy John surgery](/wiki/Tommy_John_surgery "Tommy
John surgery"), allowed players to maintain a high competitive level for a
longer time.[6] [Randy Johnson](/wiki/Randy_Johnson "Randy Johnson"), for
example, won more games in his 40s than he did in his 20s.[7]

Since 1990, only four pitchers have joined the 300 win club: [Roger
Clemens](/wiki/Roger_Clemens "Roger Clemens"), [Greg Maddux](/wiki/Greg_Maddux
"Greg Maddux"), [Tom Glavine](/wiki/Tom_Glavine "Tom Glavine"), and Johnson.
Changes in the game in the last decade of the 20th century have made attaining
300 career wins difficult, perhaps more so than during the mid 20th
century.[8] The four-man starting rotation has given way to a five-man
rotation, which gives starting pitchers fewer chances to pick up wins.[2] No
pitcher reached 20 wins in a non strike-shortened year for the first time in
2006; this was repeated in 2009 and 2017.[9]

Recording 300 career wins has been seen as a guaranteed admission to the
[Baseball Hall of Fame](/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_and_Museum
"National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum").[10][11][12] All pitchers with
300 wins have been elected to the Hall of Fame[13] except for Clemens, who
received only half of the vote total needed for induction in his first
appearance on the Hall of Fame ballot in
[2013](/wiki/Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_balloting,_2013 "Baseball Hall of Fame
balloting, 2013")[14] and lost votes from that total in
[2014](/wiki/Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_balloting,_2014 "Baseball Hall of Fame
balloting, 2014").[15] Clemens' future election is seen as uncertain because
of his alleged links to [use of performance-enhancing
drugs](/wiki/Doping_in_baseball "Doping in baseball").[16] To be eligible for
the Hall of Fame, a player must have "been retired five seasons" or deceased
for at least six months,[17] Many observers expect the club to gain few, if
any, members in the foreseeable future.[13][18][19] Ten members of the 300 win
club are also members of the [3,000 strikeout club](/wiki/3,000_strikeout_club
"3,000 strikeout club").[20]
